title: 114_hr4370
content: The "Compact Impact Relief Act of 2016" may be cited as the Act. It includes an FMAP adjustment for affected jurisdictions equivalent to compact migrant expenditures. The "Compact Impact Relief Act of 2016" increases the FMAP for affected jurisdictions based on estimated compact migrant expenditures. The chief executive official must submit expenditure estimates to the Secretary of the Interior for review before each calendar quarter. The Secretary of the Interior reviews and adjusts estimated compact migrant expenditures before each calendar quarter. The Secretary of Health and Human Services estimates the FMAP increase needed for federal payments under title XIX of the Social Security Act. The Secretary of Health and Human Services notifies chief executive officials of the estimated increase in the FMAP for federal payments under title XIX of the Social Security Act, ensuring payments do not exceed specified limitations. Health and Human Services notifies chief executive officials of the increase in the FMAP estimated by the Secretary for the affected jurisdiction. Reconciling and Payment Adjustments require affected jurisdictions to submit an accounting of migrant expenditures to the Secretary of the Interior. The Secretary of the Interior reviews and adjusts accounting submissions for accuracy, then submits a final report to the Secretary of Health and Human Services. The Secretary of Health and Human Services reviews FMAP increases and adjusts Federal payments to affected jurisdictions under title XIX of the Social Security Act. The Secretary of Health and Human Services adjusts Federal payments to affected jurisdictions under title XIX of the Social Security Act to account for any overpayment or underpayment resulting from FMAP increases. The FMAP increase for affected jurisdictions is limited to 100 percent. Compact migrant expenditures are not considered medical assistance under title XIX of the Social Security Act. Definitions include "affected jurisdiction" and "compact migrant expenditures." The FMAP increase for affected jurisdictions is limited to 100 percent for non-Federal funds expended on health care items and services for qualified nonimmigrants. This includes payments to health care providers if not made under a State plan and not from any other Federal funds source. The FMAP, or Federal medical assistance percentage, is defined in the Social Security Act without regard to this section. A conforming amendment to the Act is made to include the Compact Impact Relief Act of 2016. SEC. 3. PAYMENTS RELATING TO ELEMENTARY AND SECONDARY EDUCATION OF CITIZENS OF FREELY ASSOCIATED STATES. Amendment to the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 includes educating alien children from Freely Associated States. Payment eligibility for federally connected children is also expanded to include those who resided in the United States under certain conditions. The amendment to the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 expands payment eligibility for federally connected children, including those who resided in the United States under specific conditions. Additional funding is authorized for eligible federally connected children. Additional funding of $10,000,000 is authorized annually for federally connected children under the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965. SEC. 4 amends the Housing and Community Development Act to give preference to US citizens or nationals over aliens for housing financial assistance in Guam and the Northern Mariana Islands. SEC. 5 calls for an independent assessment of the strategic relationship between the US and the Marshall Islands, Micronesia, and Palau. The Secretary of State is required to seek an agreement with an eligible organization to conduct an independent assessment of the strategic importance of the relationship between the United States and the Republic of the Marshall Islands, the Federated States of Micronesia, and the Republic of Palau. This assessment includes evaluating the relationships as part of the Asia-Pacific re-balance, assessing the capabilities of US Government agencies in administering the Compact of Free Association. The eligible organization will assess the US Government agencies' shortcomings in administering the Compacts of Free Association with the Marshall Islands and Micronesia, as well as financial support to Palau. Recommendations for improvements, renewal of Compacts, and other relevant matters will be included in the report due within a year. The eligible organization entering into an agreement must submit a report to the Secretary of State within one year of the Act's enactment. The report should include the assessment, required matters, and any other relevant details determined by the Secretary. The report must be in unclassified form, with a classified annex if needed. The eligible organization can obtain official data directly from US departments or agencies to carry out the agreement. The head of the department or agency must provide the information upon request.
